Name: Spirotetramat
Description: Spirotetramat is an azaspiro compound that is methoxycyclohexane which is fused at position 4 to the 5-position of a 1,5-dihydro-2H-pyrrol-2-one that is substituted at positions 3 and 4 by 2,5-dimethylphenyl and (ethoxycarbonyl)oxy groups, respectively (the cis isomer). It is a proinsecticide (via hydrolysis of the ethyl carbonate group to give the corresponding 4-hydroxypyrrol-2-one, "spirotetramat-enol") and is used for the control of a wide range of sucking insects on fruit and potato crops. It has a role as a proinsecticide, an EC 6.4.1.2 (acetyl-CoA carboxylase) inhibitor and an agrochemical. It is a member of benzenes, an azaspiro compound, a carbonate ester, a gamma-lactam and a member of pyrroles.

plant_translocations.content: In this study, we investigated the impact of the mixed-application with pymetrozine on the behavior (i.e., uptake, translocation, and degradation) of spirotetramat in tomatoes under laboratory conditions. Results showed that pymetrozine promoted the uptake of spirotetramat from the nutrition solution after root application. The root concentration factor was 0.290 and 1.566 after spirotetramat single application and mixed-application with pymetrozine, respectively. It had little effect on the degradation of spirotetramat, with the metabolites of M-keto, M-enol, and M-glu in tomato issue (root, stems, and leaves). After foliar treatments, pymetrozine accelerated the translocation of spirotetramat from leaves to stems, with the translocation factor of 0.145 and 0.402 after spirotetramat single application and mixtures with pymetrozine, respectively. Pymetrozine also promoted the degradation of spirotetramat to M-kto and M-enol in leaves. Besides, a partition-limited model was used to describe the distribution processes of spirotetramat in the tomato-water system after root application. It showed that pymetrozine accelerated the distribution balance of spirotetramat in the whole system. Our result indicates that the interaction among pesticides should be considered when studied for the uptake, translocation, and degradation of pesticides in crops.
plant_translocations.reference: Liu, G., Feng, X., Wan, Y., Liu, Q., Liu, Y., & Dong, J. (2022). Uptake, translocation, and degradation of spirotetramat in tomato (Lycopersicon esculentum Miller): Impact of the mixed-application with pymetrozine. Environmental Science and Pollution Research, 29(40), 60133-60144.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Tomato seeds were germinated on water-moistened filter papers at 25°C in the dark for 3 days, then transferred to a seeding tray containing vermiculite and nutrient soil (v/v = 3/1). The seeding tray was incubated in an incubator at 25°C (16 h, day cycle) and 20°C (8 h, night cycle) with a humidity of 70% for 10 days. Seedlings were then transferred to nutrient solution to continue growing for another 3 weeks.
method.Chemical Preparation: Spirotetramat TC and pymetrozine TC were dissolved with acetone and dimethyl sulfoxide, respectively, and then diluted to 500 mg/L with water for subsequent experiments of pesticide exposure.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Root treatment involved exposing tomato roots to nutrient solution containing spirotetramat at a concentration of 5 mg/L (treatment 1) and a mixture of spirotetramat and pymetrozine, each at a concentration of 5 mg/L (treatment 2). For foliar spray, the application dose was the same as that of root treatment.
method.Other Information: Each box contained 15 tomato seedlings. Sampling was done at time intervals of 6 hours, 12 hours, 1, 3, 5, 7, 10, and 14 days, with 10 tomato seedlings randomly selected for each sampling.

plant_translocations.content: The extensive application of pesticides in agricultural activities has raised increasing concerns about crop contamination by pesticide residues, especially in vegetables. However, information about the transfer and cell diffusion characteristics of pesticides in vegetables is insufficient. In this study, we investigated the uptake, translocation, and subcellular distribution behaviors of four commonly used pesticides in Chinese cabbage (Brassica rapa var. chinensis) under laboratory hydroponic conditions. Root uptake of pesticides followed the order of fenbuconazole > avermectin > thiamethoxam > spirotetramat. Thiamethoxam was more readily translocated from the root to the shoot, while spirotetramat, fenbuconazole, and avermectin preferentially accumulated in the root. Cell soluble components were the dominant storage compartment for thiamethoxam, while the majority of spirotetramat, fenbuconazole, and avermectin were partitioned into the cell walls. These findings contribute to our understanding of pesticide bioconcentration behavior in food crops and help in evaluating the threats of pesticide residues to human health via the food chain.
plant_translocations.reference: Wang, Wenfeng; Wan, Qun; Li, Yixin; Xu, Wenjun; Yu, Xiangyang  (2019). Uptake, translocation and subcellular distribution of pesticides in Chinese cabbage (Brassica rapa var. chinensis). Ecotoxicology and Environmental Safety, 183(), 109488-doi:10.1016/j.ecoenv.2019.109488

method.Plant Growth Condition: Seeds surface sterilized, germinated 3d, then transplanted to pots with full-strength Hoagland's nutrient solution (pH 6.0) in plant incubator at 130±5 μmol/m2s light, 16h photoperiod, 60% RH, 25/20°C day/night temp. Solution renewed every 5d.
method.Chemical Preparation: Thiamethoxam, spirotetramat, fenbuconazole, avermectin standards (>99% purity). 1000 mg/L stock solutions in acetonitrile. Exposure at 10 mg/L in nutrient solution.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: 20d old uniform seedlings exposed by transferring to 100 mL beakers with 65 mL nutrient solution spiked at 10 mg/L for each pesticide.
method.Other Information: Triplicate beakers per pesticide sampled at 0.5, 6, 12, 24h. Sampled solution and rinsed seedlings separated into roots/shoots, weighed, extracted. HPLC-MS/MS analysis. Extraction efficiencies checked by spiking at 2, 5, 10 mg/L with 81.9-103.7% recoveries.

plant_translocations.content: Spirotetramat (Movento®) is a systemic insecticide that is used to control scale insects on kiwifruit. The use of protectant copper sprays on kiwifruit has become increasingly common due to the bacterial disease Pseudomonas syringae pv. actinidiae. This study investigated the interaction of copper with spirotetramat and how it influenced the uptake and translocation of spirotetramat within the plant. Movento® 100SC sprays should not be tank mixed with copper sprays because the uptake and translocation of spirotetramat is likely to be compromised. These negative effects were minimised when an organosilicone/organic fluid blend adjuvant (Du-Wett®) was included in the tank mix. Pre-and post spray applications of copper, at least 1 week either side of spirotetramat applications, are unlikely to significantly affect the uptake and translocation of spirotetramat, and thus have any effect on its activity. There were no marked differences between two commercial copper formulations, in their effects on spirotetramat uptake but minor differences in translocation were observed.
plant_translocations.reference: Horgan, D. B., & Gaskin, R. E. (2015). The effect of copper on the uptake and translocation of spirotetramat insecticide on kiwifruit. New Zealand Plant Protection, 68, 26-31.

method.Test Plant: Gold3 kiwifruit (Actinidia chinensis Planch. cultivar ‘Zesy002’) potted plants
method.Plant Grown Condition: Grown under glasshouse/shadehouse conditions from tissue culture, actively expanding pre-bloom, 1.5-2 m tall, typical spring growth
method.Chemical Preparation: Radiolabelled spirotetramat formulation (14C-radiolabel specific activity 3.67 MBq/mg, incorporated in Movento® 240SC formulation at 17.4 MBq/ml, 240 g/litre ai, Bayer CropScience)
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Spirotetramat applied alone at 96 g ai/ha. Spirotetramat applied in combination with DW (Du-Wett®, organosilicone/organic fluid blend adjuvant) at 40 ml/100 litres. Some treatments included cuprous oxide or copper hydroxide formulations. Additional chemicals fluopyram (500 g ai/litre, Luna® Privilege, Bayer CropScience) and methoxyfenozide insecticide (240 g ai/litre, Prodigy™, Dow AgroSciences) were combined within two treatment mixes
method.Other Information: Each treatment was replicated on six randomly selected, mature, fully expanded leaves from six separate plants

plant_translocations.content: In this study, the uptake, transport, and subcellular distribution of the pesticides pymetrozine and spirotetramat, along with spirotetramat metabolites B-enol, B-glu, B-mono, and B-keto, were investigated under hydroponic conditions. The results showed that both spirotetramat and pymetrozine had high bioconcentration in lettuce roots, with root concentration factor (RCF) values exceeding 1 after 24 hours of exposure. Pymetrozine exhibited higher translocation from roots to shoots compared to spirotetramat. Pymetrozine was primarily absorbed in roots via the symplastic pathway and stored in the soluble fraction of lettuce root and shoot cells. Spirotetramat and its metabolites showed major enrichments in the cell wall and soluble fractions of root cells. In lettuce shoot cells, spirotetramat and B-enol were mainly enriched in the soluble fraction, while B-keto and B-glu accumulated in cell walls and organelles, respectively. Both symplastic and apoplastic pathways were involved in spirotetramat absorption. The uptake of pymetrozine and spirotetramat by lettuce roots was passive, with no aquaporin-mediated dissimilation or diffusion. These findings improve our understanding of the transfer of these pesticides and their metabolites from the environment to lettuce, as well as their subsequent bioaccumulation. The study suggests a new approach for efficient lettuce pest control using spirotetramat and pymetrozine, while also highlighting the importance of evaluating the food safety and environmental risks associated with these compounds and their metabolites.
plant_translocations.reference: Liu, G., Feng, X., Guo, Y., Wang, X., An, K., Dong, J., & Liu, Y. (2023). Uptake and Biotransformation of Spirotetramat and Pymetrozine in Lettuce (Lactuca sativa L. var. ramosa Hort.). Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, 71(22), 8356-8366.

method.Test Plant: Italian lettuce (Lactuca sativa L. var. ramosa Hort. 151)
method.Apply Location: Root application (pesticides added to hydroponic nutrient solution)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Lettuce seeds were surface sterilized, germinated on moist filter paper for 3 days at 25°C, then transplanted to black plastic pots and grown in full-strength Hoagland nutrient solution in a plant incubator (130±5 μmol/m2.s light intensity, 16h light/8h dark photoperiod, 60% relative humidity, 25/20°C day/night temperature).
method.Chemical Preparation: Pymetrozine and spirotetramat (>96% purity) were purchased. Standard pymetrozine (>97% purity), spirotetramat (>98% purity) and its metabolites B-enol, B-keto, B-mono, B-glu (purities >94-99%) were also obtained commercially.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: 5 mg/L pymetrozine and 5 mg/L spirotetramat were separately added to the hydroponic nutrient solutions. 15 batches of lettuce seedlings were transferred to opaque pots with 5L spiked nutrient solutions.
method.Other Information: 15 blank control seedlings were grown in unspiked nutrient solution.
